title: Unchecked URL in attachment datasource

profile.name: Open-Xchange
profile.about: Messaging, collaboration and office productivity software for service providers

vulnerability_information:
Implementation of *com.openexchange.url.mail.attachment* datasource does no validation of *url* parameter. Any URL supported by Java's *URLConnection* can be read.

Attached is an exploit which reads */etc/hostname* file from sandbox server.

## Impact

Any URL supported by Java's *URLConnection* can be read.
vulnerability_information_html:
Implementation of com.openexchange.url.mail.attachment datasource does no validation of url parameter. Any URL supported by Java's URLConnection can be read.

Attached is an exploit which reads /etc/hostname file from sandbox server.

Impact

Any URL supported by Java's URLConnection can be read.

activities.message:
Hi @zhutyra 
Can you provide more steps to produce the bug?
Regards,
@bugseeker
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @zhutyra
Can you provide more steps to produce the bug?
Regards,
@bugseeker

activities.message:
I'm sorry, I should have mention that it is in AJAX API. I'm new to OX, but I don't think these fields are exposed in UI.

Only way I know at the moment is to use custom client and there just specify arbitrary URL in the call. Provided program does exactly that, so steps to reproduce would be to run it. You may need to install python requests library first (pip3 install requests).

It creates new Task, attaches an attachment with file:// URL and then reads the attachment back. The file to attach/read is specified at the top of script, so you can change it to /etc/passwd or anything more recognizable than /etc/hostname if you wish.

Regards,
@princeofpersia

activities.message:
I apologize again, I expected it to go directly to vendor familiar with the product.

*OX* has concept of *Data Sources* which produce data based on given parameters.

Through **/ajax/attachment?action=attach** endpoint it is possible to create an attachment (to whatever accepts attachments, like Tasks or Mails) and specify its data source. Request body could look like this:

```json
{
    "module": 0,
    "folder": 1,
    "attached": 2,
    "datasource": {
        "identifier": "com.openexchange.url.mail.attachment",
        "url": "file:///etc/hostname"
    }
}
```

Handling of such request in source code is implemented here:

```
backend/com.openexchange.server/src/com/openexchange/ajax/Attachment.java
backend/com.openexchange.server/src/com/openexchange/ajax/request/AttachmentRequest.java
```

One of possible data sources is **com.openexchange.url.mail.attachment** which accepts single parameter **url** and
returns content of that URL.

In source code it is implemented here:
```
backend/com.openexchange.url.mail.attachment/src/com/openexchange/url/mail/attachment/URLMailAttachmentDataSource.java
```
The specified URL is not validated so any URL supported by Java's URLConnection can be read and its content used as attachment. Supported protocols are jar, ftp(s), http(s), file, and maybe more.

Simple demo exploit which attaches content of */etc/hostname* file to a Task is attached in initial report.

Hopefully it is clearer now :)

In source code it is implemented here:

The specified URL is not validated so any URL supported by Java's URLConnection can be read and its content used as attachment. Supported protocols are jar, ftp(s), http(s), file, and maybe more.

activities.message: Thanks @zhutyra, we're looking into this report now.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks @zhutyra, we're looking into this report now.

activities.message:
Thanks for reporting this vulnerability to us. We take your feedback very serious and started the process of resolving and delivering a solution to our users. Please note that we will take care about public disclosure of the vulnerability and give our users a chance to update to a fixed version before. Therefor, please handle this finding with discretion until we publicly disclosed it.

We'll discuss the matter of bounty for this finding soon and will update you shortly. Would you like to be included in our advisories "researcher credits"?

activities.message: We solved this vulnerability internally and will provide a backport to in-production releases during the next weeks.

activities.message:
Hello,

thank you very much for the bounty.

But are you sure it's just a Medium? I mean, the content can be read back and may be a file, which has previously qualified as a higher severity.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello,

thank you very much for the bounty.

But are you sure it's just a Medium? I mean, the content can be read back and may be a file, which has previously qualified as a higher severity.

activities.message:
Thanks for your comment, "medium" is the label H1 choose based on our CVSS of 6.5, which i would not consider "medium". We considered this finding a "high" severity rating for the confidentiality criteria:

> High: There is total loss of confidentiality, resulting in all resources within the impacted component being divulged to the attacker. Alternatively, access to only some restricted information is obtained, but the disclosed information presents a direct, serious impact.
activities.markdown_message:
